Answers.MP Summary: adjust backlight brightness using RandR extension
Top-3 Similar Questions: au_490725: set the screen brightness on startup
ul_109568: How do I get my laptop screen backlight brightness controls to work?
au_823669: Volume sound and screen brightness controls not working
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_109568: $ xbacklight +30% # increases brightness by 30 percent
$ xbacklight -30% # decreases brightness by 30 percent

au_823669: sudo apt-get update; sudo apt-get install xbacklight alsa-utils pulseaudio

# Pulse Audio controls
bindsym XF86AudioRaiseVolume exec --no-startup-id pactl -- set-sink-volume 0 +5% #increase sound volume
bindsym XF86AudioLowerVolume exec --no-startup-id pactl -- set-sink-volume 0 -5% #decrease sound volume
bindsym XF86AudioMute exec --no-startup-id pactl set-sink-mute 0 toggle # mute sound

# Sreen brightness controls
bindsym XF86MonBrightnessUp exec xbacklight -inc 20 # increase screen brightness
bindsym XF86MonBrightnessDown exec xbacklight -dec 20 # decrease screen brightness

Explanations about Options.-dec: Decreases brightness by the specified amount.
Explanations about Options.-set: Sets each backlight brightness to the specified level.
Explanations about Options.-inc: Increases brightness by the specified amount.

Explanations about Options.--brightness:
Multiply the gamma values on the crtc currently attached to the output to specified
 floating value. Useful for overly bright or overly dim outputs. However, this is a
 software only modification, if your hardware has support to actually change the
 brightness, you will probably prefer to use xbacklight.
Explanations about Options.--output: Selects an output to reconfigure. Use either the name of the output or the XID.
